document.title: The Gottschalk-Hedlund theorem, cocycles, and small divisors

para.p: This note consists of my working through details in the paper Resonances and small divisors by Étienne Ghys. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1 http://perso.ens-lyon.fr/ghys/articles/resonancesmall.pdf Aside from containing mathematics, Ghys makes thoughtful remarks about the history of physics, unlike the typically thoughtless statements people make about the Ptolemaic system. He insightfully states “Kepler’s zeroth law”: “If the orbit of a planet is bounded, then it is periodic.” I can certainly draw a three dimensional bounded curve that is not closed, but that curve is not the orbit of a planet. It is also intellectually lazy to scorn Kepler’s correspondence between orbits and the Platonic solids (“Kepler’s fourth law”).

Suppose that
: f
→ R C
is continuous. For
> ϵ 0

∈ T R
an
ϵ

f
if

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(f * (t + T) - f * t) less epsilon, t element-of R)

para.p:
T
is a period of
f
if and only if it is an
ϵ

> ϵ 0

. Thus, for every

I
is an interval of length
>
M
then there is an
ϵ
-period in
I
. Therefore, with a periodic function, the length of the intervals
I
need not depend on
ϵ
, while for an almost periodic function they may.

The Gottschalk-Hedlund theorem is stated and proved in Katok and Hasselblatt. 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 Anatole Katok and Boris Hasselblat, Introduction to the Modern Theory of Dynamical Systems, p. 102, Theorem 2.9.4. The following case of the Gottschalk-Hedlund theorem is from Ghys. We denote by

Math.text: pi _ 1 colon ((R / Z) * R to list@(R / Z, pi _ 2)) colon ((R / Z) * R to R)

para.p: the projection maps.

In this section I am following Tao. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 Terence Tao, Cohomology for dynamical systems, http://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/12/21/cohomology-for-dynamical-systems/ Suppose that a group
( G , ⋅ )
acts on a set
X
and that
( A , + )
is an abelian group. A cocycle is a function
: ρ
→
× G X
A
such that

Math.text: formulae@(rho * open-interval@(g * h, x) = list@(rho * open-interval@(h, x) + rho * open-interval@(g, h * x), g), formulae@(h element-of G, x element-of X))

para.p:
If
: F
→ X A
is a function, we call the function
=
⁢ ρ
( g , x )
-
⁢ F
(
⁢ g x
)
⁢ F
( x )
a coboundary. This satisfies

Math.text: rho * open-interval@(g * h, x) - rho * open-interval@(g, h * x) = (F * g * h * x - F * x - F * g * h * x) + F * h * x = F * h * x - F * x = rho * open-interval@(h, x)

para.p:
showing that a coboundary is a cocycle. We now show how to fit the notions of cocycle and coboundary into a general sitting of cohomology. We show that they correspond respectively to a
1
-cocycle and a
1
-coboundary.

≥ n 0

n

X

n

n

⁢

( G , X )

Z

vector@(g _ 1, ldots, g _ (n - 1), g _ n * x)
+ (- 1) ^ n * vector@(g _ 2, ldots, g _ n, x)

Let
α

para.p:
Supposing that for each
x
,
⁢ v
( x )
is equal to its Fourier series evaluated at
x
and that its Fourier series converges absolutely,

Math.text: v * x = (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(widehat@(v) * n * e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * x))

then for each
∈ x

Math.text: v * (x + alpha) - v * x = (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(widehat@(v) * n * (e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * (x + alpha)) - e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * x))) = (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(widehat@(v) * n * (e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * alpha) - 1) * e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * x))

Then using

Math.text: formulae@(widehat@(u) * n = widehat@(v) * n * (e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * alpha) - 1), n element-of Z)

para.p: or,

Math.text: formulae@(widehat@(v) * n = (widehat@(u) * n) / (e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * alpha) - 1), n not-equals 0)

para.p:
because
α
is irrational, the denominator of the right-hand side is indeed nonzero for
≠ n 0
. The value of
⁢
^ v
( 0 )
is not determined so far. We shall find conditions under which the continuous function
v
we desire can be defined using ().

A real number
β
is said to be Diophantine if there is some
≥ r 2
and some
> C 0
such that for all
> q 0
and
∈ p Z
,

Math.text: absolute-value@(beta - p / q) > C * q ^ (- r)

para.p:
It is immediate that a Diophantine number is irrational. Suppose that
α
satisfies (). Let
≠ n 0
and let
p n
be the integer nearest
⁢ n α
. Then

Math.text: absolute-value@(e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * alpha) - 1) = absolute-value@(e ^ (2 * pi * i * (n * alpha - p _ n)) - 1) >= (2 / pi) * absolute-value@(2 * pi * (n * alpha - p _ n)) = 4 * absolute-value@(n * alpha - p _ n) = 4 * absolute-value@(n) * absolute-value@(alpha - p _ n / n) > ((4 * absolute-value@(n)) cdot C) * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ (- r) = 4 * C * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ ((- r) + 1)
absolute-value@(e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * alpha) - 1)
absolute-value@(e ^ (2 * pi * i * (n * alpha - p _ n)) - 1)
(2 / pi) * absolute-value@(2 * pi * (n * alpha - p _ n))
4 * absolute-value@(n * alpha - p _ n)
4 * absolute-value@(n) * absolute-value@(alpha - p _ n / n)
((4 * absolute-value@(n)) cdot C) * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ (- r)
4 * C * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ ((- r) + 1)

para.p:
Because
∈ u
C ∞
, it is straightforward to prove that for each nonnegative integer
k
there is some

para.p:
Therefore, for each nonnegative integer
k
, using () we have

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(widehat@(v) * n) = absolute-value@(widehat@(u) * n) / absolute-value@(e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * alpha) - 1) less (C _ k * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ (- k)) cdot (1 / (4 * C * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ ((- r) + 1))) = (C _ k / (4 * C)) * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ (r - k - 1), n not-equals 0)

para.p:
One can prove that if
h n
are complex numbers satisfying () then the function defined by

Math.text: formulae@(h * x = (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(h _ n * e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * x)), x element-of R / Z)
